Ê†áÈ¢ò: 4.0 out of 5 starsChocolate Good, But Label Accurate?
ËØÑËÆ∫ÂÜÖÂÆπ: The quality of the chocolate I received was excellent.  However, the box containing the candy bars had been opened before I received it, and it was apparent from the shape and the consistency of the candy bars that either the manufacturing process for them has changed, the ingredients have, or the candy bars were counterfeit.  One I threw away.Anyone with allergies should take note, and proceed with caution, although, in this instance, the issue appears likely to be specific to Amazon, as opposed to the manufacturer, whether the packaging problem occurred before Amazon received damaged product and just passed it on to consumers rather than rejecting the goods, damage occurred in the Amazon warehouse or delivery process, or occurred after delivery, when the package sat unattended because, once again, my specific written delivery instructions were completely disregarded.

Ê†áÈ¢ò: 4.0 out of 5 starsGood value especially with Subscribe & Save, but quality has been going down
ËØÑËÆ∫ÂÜÖÂÆπ: A box of 18 candy bars for $10.70 or so seems good value to me.  I order by Subscribe & Save to get that price.  A monthly delivery also helps me limit my candy bar intake.  I've probably ordered 10 boxes over the last year.  Amazon originally wrapped each box in a cooler bag for summer deliveries, but last summer they just suspended sales.  Over the last few months (Dec 2018-March 2019), quality has started to go down, particularly the 3 Musketeers and Snickers bars.  The expiry date was approx 7 months from when I received delivery (so that definitely WON'T be a problem).  However, 3 Musketeers and Snickers bars have had hard centers, so much so that I nearly broke a front tooth biting into a 3 Musketeers and it made a distinct snapping sound when I bit into it.  The centers are supposed to be light and fluffy!  Several Snickers bars were lightly crunchy, not soft and caramelly.  The chocolate coating was OK with no sign of heat damage.  There's definitely a quality-control problem here, I suspect with storage and transport.EDIT: I contacted the manufacturer Mars. They were polite but not overly interested.  They sent me two $5-off manufacturer coupons that I cannot use on Amazon.  I did my own quality control tests and discovered the bad candy bars were not sealed airtight--the heat seals at both ends of the wrapper were not sealed, allowing air to leak in and oxidize the candy.  Obviously a manufacturing problem. I let Mars know but didn't hear back from them.  I'm sure they knew it already.
